Storage Capacity: 1.27 wt%; 0.68 wt% (after 160 °C aging); 0.99–1.18 wt%; 0.43-0.99 wt%; 0.0016 wt% (ΔCapacity at 30 °C after 12 yr)
Temperature Range: 20 to 160 °C; 20–160 °C; 20–50 °C (hydrogenation/dehydrogenation) and 50–160 °C aging; 20-50 °C; 50-160 °C (90 days aging); 30-50 °C; 30 °C–50 °C; ≈350 K
Pressure Range: 3–96 bar; 0.42–6.54 bar; 20–96 bar; ≈45 bar hydrogenation, ≈0.5 bar dehydrogenation; plateau 0.67–0.78 bar (20–30 °C) and 1.28–1.67 bar (45–55 °C)
Synthesis Method: Extracted from commercial BL-30 hydrogen container (≈5 wt% PTFE); Pressure aging at 20, 35, 58 and 96 bar H₂ for 90 days at 50, 90, 130 and 160 °C
Key Findings: Accelerated aging (90 d, 20–96 bar, 50–160 °C) predicts LaNi5 performance after 12 years of space operation.; As‑received LaNi5 stores ~1.27 wt% H₂; ΔH = –27.96 ± 0.95 kJ mol⁻¹, ΔS = –100.00 ± 3.09 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹; Aging LaNi5 at 160 °C for 90 days reduces capacity to 0.68 wt% and increases hysteresis.; Aged LaNi5 retains ~1 wt% H capacity; hydrogenation reaches 90 % in ≤1 min, dehydrogenation slower at low T.; Aged LaNi5 shows 0.49 wt% H₂ capacity; hydrogenation completes within 0.3 min and dehydrogenation within 3 min across 20‑50 °C.; Dislocation density increases from 6.72×10^14 m⁻² (as‑received) to 16.77×10^14 m⁻² after 160 °C aging for 90 days.; Aging reduces LaNi5 particle size from ~116.6 nm to 38 nm at 160 °C and decreases storage capacity by ~0.152 wt% after 12 years at 30 °C.; After 12 years, LaNi5 capacity degrades 0.152% at 30 °C and 0.415% at 50 °C; plateau pressure decreases from 38.47% to 91.28%.; Eutectoid phase separation detected at ~350 K in LaNi5‑H2 system.
Comments: Material contains ~5 wt% PTFE; fully hydrogenated specimens used.; Aging at 50–160 °C reduces plateau pressures and alters thermodynamics; Capacity remains ~1.2 wt% after aging at ≤130 °C.; Plateau pressures decrease with aging; 160 °C sample shows no clear plateaus.; Lattice strain and dislocation density increase with aging temperature.; Particle size drops from 28.96 µm to 9.06 µm; micro‑cracks appear; no hydrogen‑related phase detected.; No phase segregation observed after aging.; No phase segregation observed; degradation linked to increased dislocation density and reduced particle size.; Indicates complex hydride behavior during cycling.
